author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: The Los Angeles area is hit with a Christmas coronavirus surge.
description: Los Angeles County, already in the throes of a devastating surge in coronavirus cases after Thanksgiving travel and gatherings, is being hit with a spike from Christmas festivities.
content: Los Angeles County, already in the throes of a devastating surge in coronavirus cases after Thanksgiving travel and gatherings, is being hit with a spike from Christmas festivities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Trump Calls Georgia Senate Races ‘Illegal and Invalid’
description: President Trump continued his assault on election integrity, baselessly claiming the presidential results and the Senate runoffs in Georgia were both invalid — which could complicate G.O.P. efforts to motivate voters.
content: ATLANTA — President Trump took to Twitter Friday evening to make the unfounded assertion that Georgia’s two Senate races are “illegal and invalid,” an argument that could complicate his efforts to convince his supporters to turn out for Republican candidates in the two runoff races that will determine which party controls the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Starving Children Don’t Cry
description: For several years, each year was the best in human history. Then 2020 came along.
content: Starvation is agonizing and degrading. You lose control of your bowels. Your skin peels off, your hair falls out, you hallucinate and you may go blind from lack of vitamin A. While you waste away, your body cannibalizes itself: It consumes its own muscles, even the heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink
title: Under fire, the Netherlands is speeding up the start of its lagging vaccination campaign.
description: The government said that shots would begin sooner than Jan. 8, and that it would announce the new start date on Monday.
content: Facing broad criticism, the government of the Netherlands on Saturday said the country would speed up its lagging vaccination process and provide the first shots to frontline health care workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Lauren Wolfe
title: A Virginia state senator, Ben Chafin, has died from complications of Covid-19.
description: He died after two weeks in a Richmond hospital.
content: Ben Chafin, a Republican state senator from Virginia, has died of complications of Covid-19, the State Senate’s Republican Caucus confirmed on Friday evening. He had been receiving treatment at the VCU Medical Center in Richmond for two weeks, his family said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Paul Westphal, N.B.A. Hall of Famer and Coach, Dies at 70
description: Drafted in the first round by the Celtics, he played for 12 seasons before leading teams in Phoenix, Seattle and Sacramento.
content: Paul Westphal, the Basketball Hall of Fame guard who played for the Boston Celtics’ 1974 N.B.A. champions, became a four-time All-Star with the Phoenix Suns and coached them to the league playoff final in 1993, died on Saturday. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: How Taiwan Plans to Stay (Mostly) Covid-Free
description: The island’s success against the coronavirus has created a sinking feeling for many residents: How much longer can their good fortune last?
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Consider for a moment, in this time of anguish and loss and death, of mass unemployment and flattened national economies, the Twilight Zone alternate reality that is Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Adál Maldonado, Provocative ‘Nuyorican’ Photographer, Dies at 72
description: Adál, who moved from Puerto Rico to New York as a teenager, created art that was often bitingly satirical and politically subversive.
content: Adál Maldonado, an influential Puerto Rican photographer and artistic provocateur who explored the psychological and cultural fallout of the Puerto Rican diaspora in New York, died on Dec. 9 in San Juan. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Mike Baker
title: Raphael Warnock, From the Pulpit to Politics, Doesn’t Shy From ‘Uncomfortable’ Truths
description: He first wanted to run for office years ago. Now Stacey Abrams, the Democratic Party and the Rev. Raphael Warnock all believe that the time is ripe for Georgia voters to send a Black Baptist preacher to Washington.
content: ATLANTA — For months in 2007, the Rev. Raphael Warnock used his pulpit at Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta to call for the release of a young Black man, sentenced to 10 years in prison for a consensual sexual encounter between teenagers. Some of his powerful parishioners, like the congressman and civil rights icon John Lewis, had joined the cause, even visiting the young man in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Drink That You Could Really Use
description: Joe Deeney hydrates us.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the second grid in two days with number symbols; Joe Deeney adds some star power and a number of watery elements. There’s also some interesting geometry today: an extra column, necessitated by that spelled-out 16-letter span. It's the centerpiece, but with 11 other lengthy debuts and fantastic cluing, it certainly doesn’t have to carry the rest of this excellent solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Lady of the Lakers
description: Jeanie Buss inherited a team, and a legacy, from her father. What will her imprint be?
content: In November 2015, when Kobe Bryant had decided it would be his final basketball season, he requested a meeting with Jeanie Buss, the controlling owner of the Lakers. They met at the house she was sharing with her then-fiancé, Phil Jackson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Alabama and Ohio State Reach the National Title Game With Runaway Wins
description: Notre Dame never really threatened the Crimson Tide in their College Football Playoff semifinal, and then Ohio State rolled over Clemson.
content: As Alabama running back Najee Harris took a handoff, bounced outside and headed upfield, he was confronted by Notre Dame cornerback Nick McCloud, who charged up to meet him with his shoulder lowered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Conjuring Up the World Through the Sense of Taste
description: Housebound because of the pandemic, an international correspondent finds a way to travel the globe in her kitchen.
content: BANGKOK — My grandmother in Tokyo kept a pail under her sink. It was filled with what resembled wet sand. But from its pungent depths came what I considered to be the most miraculous of treats — a pickled carrot or daikon or, one of my favorites, a bud of a ginger-like plant called myoga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Coast Guard Suspends Search for Missing Boat With 20 Aboard
description: The 29-foot boat departed from Bimini, the Bahamas, and was headed to Lake Worth Beach, Fla., officials said.
content: MIAMI — The U.S. Coast Guard suspended its search on Friday for an overdue boat that was headed to Florida from the Bahamas with 20 people aboard, after the authorities said they had exhausted their efforts to find it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Hisako Ueno, Mike Ives and Paul Mozur
title: Tokyo asks for a national state of emergency.
description: After days of record-setting coronavirus tallies in Tokyo, the city’s governor on Saturday asked Japan’s central government to declare a national state of emergency for the first time since April.
content: After days of record-setting coronavirus tallies in Tokyo, the city’s governor on Saturday asked Japan’s central government to declare a national state of emergency for the first time since April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Has Africa been spared? Researchers say the numbers of cases and deaths are probably undercounted.
description: LAGOS, Nigeria — As the pandemic has swept across the world, it has become increasingly evident that in a vast majority of countries on the African continent, most deaths are never formally registered. Reliable data on a country’s deaths and their causes are hard to come by, which means governments can miss emerging health threats — whether Ebola or the coronavirus — and often have to formulate health policy blindly.
content: LAGOS, Nigeria — As the pandemic has swept across the world, it has become increasingly evident that in a vast majority of countries on the African continent, most deaths are never formally registered. Reliable data on a country’s deaths and their causes are hard to come by, which means governments can miss emerging health threats — whether Ebola or the coronavirus — and often have to formulate health policy blindly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Packages Keep Getting Stolen. What Can I Do?
description: A 2019 analysis found that 90,000 packages are lost or stolen every day in New York. And it’s only getting worse during the pandemic.
content: Q: Packages have been getting stolen from my rental building in Sugar Hill, Harlem. We’ve been getting more packages delivered since the pandemic, and they are often left in the lobby with no protection. Tenants are working hard to notify neighbors about the deliveries, but we don’t all know each other. How do we petition our landlord for lockers or a mailroom? Would he be liable for stolen packages after he’s been put on notice? What can we do to protect our deliveries?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fahim Abed and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Targeted Killings Are Terrorizing Afghans. And No One Is Claiming Them.
description: Most officials believe the Taliban are behind the attacks on civil leaders, but others fear that factions are using chaos as a cover to settle scores, in an echo of Afghanistan’s past civil war.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — A military prosecutor who thought upholding the law was the highest honor, a doctor who inspired her family to study medicine, a journalist who wanted to hold those in power to account and a human-rights activist who sought to combat poverty in her home province: all murdered within weeks by unknown attackers as winter settled over Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Homes of Mitch McConnell and Nancy Pelosi Are Reported Vandalized
description: Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, called the vandalism of his Louisville, Ky., home a “radical tantrum” taken from a “toxic playbook.”
content: The homes of Senator Mitch McConnell and Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the two most powerful members of Congress, have been reported vandalized, days after the contentious passage of a stimulus bill that has been criticized as inadequate by a broad coalition ranging from progressive activists to President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon show us their 2021 stripes.
content: ACROSTIC — Happy new year, solvers! This looks to be a good book to draw from for our first puzzle in 2021: a memoir by Mary Morris, about how she overcame some rotten luck and tenaciously pursued a great adventure. The book borrows its title, “All the Way to the Tigers,” from “Death in Venice”; the excerpt describes Ms. Morris’s deep and longtime fascination with tigers, the mysterious striped cats, that inspires her odyssey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: ‘Year of the Reveal’: Runoffs Follow Pandemic, Protests and a Test of Atlanta’s Promise
description: The high-stakes Senate contests come after months of tumult and activism in a city often seen as both resolutely Southern and somehow distinct from the rest of the region.
content: ATLANTA — Like Atlanta itself, the rapper T.I. has known both defeat and a long twisting road toward redemption and prosperity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Eric Lipton
title: Washington Has Been Lucrative for Some on Biden’s Team
description: Janet Yellen, the president-elect’s pick for Treasury secretary, collected more than $7 million in speaking fees over the past two years. Antony J. Blinken and Avril Haines did well, too.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice for Treasury secretary, Janet L. Yellen, collected more than $7 million in speaking fees over the past two years from major corporations and Wall Street banks that have a keen interest in the financial policies she will oversee after her expected confirmation to lead the Treasury Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Furber and Will Wright
title: Family Members of Man Killed by Minneapolis Police Say Raid Left Them Shaken
description: The father of a 23-year-old man killed by Minneapolis police officers learned of his son’s death only after police officers searched his home in the middle of the night.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Bayle Gelle said he awoke in the middle of the night to the sound of his wife screaming. He plunged shirtless down the stairs and found her in the living room, being confronted by sheriff’s deputies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Some Covid Survivors Haunted by Loss of Smell and Taste
description: As the coronavirus claims more victims, a once-rare diagnosis is receiving new attention from scientists, who fear it may affect nutrition and mental health.
content: Until March, when everything started tasting like cardboard, Katherine Hansen had such a keen sense of smell that she could recreate almost any restaurant dish at home without the recipe, just by recalling the scents and flavors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geneva Abdul
title: A Canadian ‘Buy Local’ Effort Fights Amazon on Its Own Turf
description: A website called Not Amazon was created to drive sales to more than 4,000 independent stores in four cities. The initiative aims to keep expanding.
content: TORONTO — The snow was falling outside Ali Haberstroh’s apartment in late November when the idea came to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Gunfire and Crashing Cars: In Struggling Neighborhoods, ‘We’re Losing Our Grip’
description: A year of hardship in parts of Cleveland has left many with the sense that the fabric of their communities was fraying.
content: CLEVELAND — When evening arrives, Darryl Brazil sits on his porch and watches the world fall apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Schwartz
title: Canada will require incoming international air passengers to test negative before boarding, and other news from around the world.
description: Canada will require passengers seeking to board international flights into the country to show their airline proof of a negative coronavirus test, in addition to entering an already existing, mandatory 14-day quarantine on arrival.
content: Canada will require passengers seeking to board international flights into the country to show their airline proof of a negative coronavirus test, in addition to entering an already existing, mandatory 14-day quarantine on arrival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth and Julian E. Barnes
title: As Understanding of Russian Hacking Grows, So Does Alarm
description: Those behind the widespread intrusion into government and corporate networks exploited seams in U.S. defenses and gave away nothing to American monitoring of their systems.
content: On Election Day, General Paul M. Nakasone, the nation’s top cyberwarrior, reported that the battle against Russian interference in the presidential campaign had posted major successes and exposed the other side’s online weapons, tools and tradecraft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Pence Welcomes Futile Bid by G.O.P. Lawmakers to Overturn Election
description: Vice President Mike Pence signaled his support as 11 Republican senators and senators-elect said that they would vote to reject President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
content: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence signaled support on Saturday for a futile Republican bid to overturn the election in Congress next week, after 11 Republican senators and senators-elect said that they would vote to reject President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory when the House and Senate meet to formally certify it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: The New Orleans Saints’ star running back, Alvin Kamara, is placed on the N.F.L.’s Covid reserve list.
description: Alvin Kamara, the star running back for the New Orleans Saints and one of the best players in the N.F.L. this season, has been placed on the N.F.L.’s Covid-19 reserve list, a move that will keep him out of the team’s regular-season finale on Sunday and that may jeopardize his chances to appear in the team’s first game of the playoffs.
content: Alvin Kamara, the star running back for the New Orleans Saints and one of the best players in the N.F.L. this season, has been placed on the N.F.L.’s Covid-19 reserve list, a move that will keep him out of the team’s regular-season finale on Sunday and that may jeopardize his chances to appear in the team’s first game of the playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla Says It Hit Goal of Delivering 500,000 Cars in 2020
description: The milestone seemed unreachable just three years ago and comes as Tesla has seen a string of profitable quarters and a buoyant stock.
content: The electric carmaker Tesla reported on Saturday that it had produced more than half a million cars in 2020, a milestone that seemed unreachable just three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s the First Thing You Will Do When the Pandemic Ends?
description: We put that question to readers and received more than 800 responses. Here are some of the highlights.
content: Though public health officials have cautioned that the coronavirus pandemic is far from over, the rollout of vaccines around the world signals the start of a hopeful chapter after nearly a year of lockdowns, restrictions and social distancing. Now that imagining an “after time” seems possible, At Home readers were asked to share their “firsts” — the first things they plan to do when the world returns to normal.  A total of 803 readers responded, with plans for hugs, family visits and dream trips that have been delayed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Fleeing Lockdown, Americans Are Flocking to Mexico City
description: Hospitals are at capacity and coronavirus cases are surging, but many foreigners, especially Americans, are heading to the Mexican capital — some intending to stay awhile.
content: MEXICO CITY — At first, life in lockdown was OK, between working from home, exercising with his roommate, and devouring everything on Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Maggie Haberman
title: Federal Judge Dismisses Election Lawsuit Against Pence
description: President Trump’s congressional allies had hoped to give the vice president the power to reject electoral votes that were cast for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday dismissed a lawsuit led by President Trump’s allies in Congress that aimed to pressure Vice President Mike Pence to overturn the results of the election, dealing a blow to lawmakers’ last-ditch effort to challenge President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Catie Edmondson
title: As Some Deficit Hawks Turn Dove, the New Politics of Debt Are on Display
description: Some Republicans who once scolded about fiscal austerity are now embracing government spending, underlining that the public supports more generous relief.
content: Over the past four years, President Trump and his allies in Congress have all but obliterated the Republican Party’s self-professed commitment to less spending and smaller deficits, pushing policies that have bloated the federal budget deficit to record levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A Season of Chaos Will End With a Powerhouse Matchup College Football Wanted
description: Alabama and Ohio State took different paths to the national championship game, with twists that showed how much college football wanted its biggest stage to feel familiar.
content: Set aside, for just a moment, the coronavirus pandemic and all of the disruptions it dealt to the college football season — the week-to-week teetering, the postponements, the cancellations, the thousands of virus cases and the contact traces. Now consider the two teams that have ascended to a championship whose very staging will long be debated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: He Calmed Gaza, Aided Israel’s Arab Ties and Preserved Hopes for Peace
description: After six years of quiet diplomacy as the U.N.’s Middle East envoy, Nickolay Mladenov leaves his post to a chorus of praise from an unlikely choir.
content: JERUSALEM — Preventive diplomacy, by its nature, does not often lead to splashy headlines for the practitioner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Hinga Klein
title: 25 California prisons have logged more than 1,000 infections. None are in the first wave of vaccinations.
description: California’s prison system, which has been exceptionally hard-hit by the coronavirus, has started vaccinating some inmates — but none so far at the 25 prisons that have been most overwhelmed by infections, including San Quentin, Avenal State Prison and the California Institution for Men.
content: California’s prison system, which has been exceptionally hard-hit by the coronavirus, has started vaccinating some inmates — but none so far at the 25 prisons that have been most overwhelmed by infections, including San Quentin, Avenal State Prison and the California Institution for Men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Tim Severin, Seafarer Who Replicated Explorers’ Journeys, Dies at 80
description: He and his crew sailed from Ireland to Newfoundland in a 36-foot boat like the one a sixth-century monk is believed to have used to cross the Atlantic.
content: Tim Severin, a British adventurer who for 40 years meticulously replicated the journeys of real and mythic explorers like St. Brendan the Navigator, Sinbad the Sailor and Marco Polo, died on Dec. 18 at his home in West Cork, Ireland. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: ‘From Crisis to Crisis’: The Moments That Defined a Historic Congress
description: The 116th Congress has lurched through a government shutdown, the impeachment and trial of a president, and the deadliest pandemic in a century.
content: WASHINGTON — It began with a pair of firsts, one hopeful and one grim: The most diverse Congress in the nation’s history was sworn in two years ago during the longest government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: India nears approval for two vaccines.
description: An expert coronavirus panel in India has recommended authorizing the vaccine created by AstraZeneca and Oxford University, as well as a local candidate, for emergency use.
content: An expert coronavirus panel in India has recommended authorizing the vaccine created by AstraZeneca and Oxford University, as well as a local candidate, for emergency use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: A Continent Where the Dead Are Not Counted
description: All 54 African countries put together have registered fewer Covid deaths than France. That doesn’t mean people aren’t dying from the virus.
content: LAGOS, Nigeria — Christopher Johnson was known for two things. His enthusiastic dancing in the street, which made everyone laugh. And his habit of hurling insults at strangers, which constantly got him into trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Degner and Stacy Cowley
title: The Vegas Chapels Are Open, and Waiting
description: The pandemic did not stop a Las Vegas tradition: the fast, budget-priced nuptial ceremony with you and your very own (socially distant) Elvis impersonator.
content: For couples seeking a quickie wedding, or a whimsical one, Las Vegas is ready.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neelesh Misra
title: Do Children Really Need to Learn to Code?
description: In India, parents are being aggressively sold the idea that their children must start coding at 4 or 5 or be future failures.
content: LUCKNOW, India — I am a parent, and this is my little mutiny. I withdrew my 5-year-old daughter, Vaidehi, from her school in this northern India city. The school had 110 students joining each online class, all of them instructed to be in their school uniforms. India has about 10 million coronavirus cases now, and schools have been offering online instruction since March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Blake Griffin: Thriving Away From the Rim and Feeling ‘Ancient’
description: At 31, Griffin is a Detroit Pistons elder who still knows how to entertain, even if soaring dunks are no longer his specialty.
content: There must be some mistake. There is no way Blake Griffin, the star forward for the Detroit Pistons, is in his 11th N.B.A. season. Wasn’t he just soaring over the hood of a Kia to win the slam dunk contest? Being schooled in “dunkology” by Jeff Goldblum? That was almost a decade ago?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Busting Moves
description: Paolo Pasco trips the light fantastic.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We have had a long run of excellent and tricky themeless weekend puzzles from Paolo Pasco, so when I saw his name today, I anticipated a lot of complexity and intrigue. I didn’t realize that this is only his second Sunday puzzle for the Times. This is unacceptable: Mr. Pasco is practically out of college (a junior at Harvard, majoring in computer science), and should have ramped up his construction pace by now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Sudden Sisterhood of Covid Widows, United in Unthinkable Loss
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 2, 2021.
content: “I think it could have made a difference, if I was there seeing him, to soothe him or scratch his arm or kiss his head.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Easy Weeknight Recipes You Need
description: Whether you’ve got 10 minutes or an hour, we’ve got you covered.
content: With January upon us you may be thinking, “Now what do I cook?” There’s no better time to get inspired by ingenious weeknight meals — and we have lots of them. Go meatless with Yewande Komolafe’s crispy tofu with cashews and blistered snap peas (above), make a delicious lemon-caper pan sauce to accompany Toni Tipton-Martin’s pork chops, or liven up Alexa Weibel’s creamy white bean soup with spicy paprika oil. We have all the collections and recipes you need in the link below, whether you have 10 minutes or an hour to get food on the table. (Sign up here to receive the Five Weeknight Dishes newsletter in your inbox every Friday.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The Year of Buyer’s Remorse
description: In 2020 we stocked up on a lot. Maybe some things we didn’t need.
content: Jenn Takahashi remembers March 27 as the date she panic-bought a Nintendo Switch Lite. She realized her colleagues were playing an online game called Animal Crossing in which your character, usually an anthropomorphic animal, moves to a deserted island, helps develop it, and then hangs out there with other creatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Wreckage Betsy DeVos Leaves Behind
description: The Education Department lies in ruins right when it’s needed most.
content: The departing education secretary, Betsy DeVos, will be remembered as perhaps the most disastrous leader in the Education Department’s history. Her lack of vision has been apparent in a variety of contexts, but never more so than this fall when she told districts that were seeking guidance on how to operate during the coronavirus pandemic that it was not her responsibility to track school district infection rates or keep track of school reopening plans. This telling remark implies a vision of the Education Department as a mere bystander in a crisis that disrupted the lives of more than 50 million schoolchildren.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Texas Hires Steve Sarkisian, Alabama’s Offensive Coordinator, as Coach
description: The move came several hours after the university announced it had fired Tom Herman, whose contract dictates a hefty buyout.
content: Texas said Saturday that it had fired Tom Herman as its football coach and, hours later, announced that it had hired the wizard at the helm of top-ranked Alabama’s offense in a bid to restore the Longhorns to championship contention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Rowing the Nile: A Soothing Respite in a Chaotic Metropolis
description: Ancient pharaohs rowed the Nile. Now Egyptians have rediscovered the practice, finding a new perspective on the river that shaped their country.
content: CAIRO — Sunset is when the Nile blinks to life in Cairo, the party boats twinkling like Vegas, the couples on the Qasr el-Nil bridge lingering in the breeze, the riverside cafes clinking with commerce long past most cities’ bedtimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Safina and David Rothenberg
title: This Rescue Moose Was Also 2020
description: Let’s celebrate the strange and marvelous creatures of Earth while we still can.
content: Let’s celebrate the strange and marvelous creatures of Earth while we still can.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ensuring the Survival of Our Democracy
description: “Mr. Trump may have weakened our democracy, but whether that weakening is fatal is up to us,” a reader writes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Has Feminism Achieved?
description: Readers take issue with an Op-Ed suggesting that the pandemic has undone the advances in gender equity.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 2, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 2, 2021.
content: An article this weekend on Page 16 about a patient who had hereditary angioedema refers incorrectly to a protein that blocks swelling and inflammation. It is C1-inhibitor, not C1.
source.name: The New York Times
